Uses of Interface
structures.BinaryTreeNode

    • Uses of BinaryTreeNode in structures

      Methods in structures that return BinaryTreeNode 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      BinaryTreeNode<T> BinaryTreeNode.getLeftChild()
      Returns the left child of this BinaryTreeNode.
      BinaryTreeNode<T> BinaryTreeNode.getRightChild()
      Returns the right child of this BinaryTreeNode.
      BinaryTreeNode<T> BinarySearchTree.toBinaryTreeNode()
      Returns a BinaryTreeNode that is consistent with the internal shape of this BinarySearchTree.
      Methods in structures with parameters of type BinaryTreeNode 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      <T> int BinaryTreeUtility.getDepth​(BinaryTreeNode<T> root)
      Given a BinaryTreeNode computes the maximum distance that can be traveled from root to some child BinaryTreeNode.
      <T> java.util.Iterator<T> BinaryTreeUtility.getInOrderIterator​(BinaryTreeNode<T> root)
      Creates a new Iterator that traverses the specified BinaryTreeNode in in-order.
      <T> java.util.Iterator<T> BinaryTreeUtility.getPostOrderIterator​(BinaryTreeNode<T> root)
      Creates a new Iterator that traverses the specified BinaryTreeNode in post-order.
      <T> java.util.Iterator<T> BinaryTreeUtility.getPreOrderIterator​(BinaryTreeNode<T> root)
      Creates a new Iterator that traverses the specified BinaryTreeNode in pre-order.
      <T> boolean BinaryTreeUtility.isBalanced​(BinaryTreeNode<T> root, int tolerance)
      A binary tree is said to be balanced if for each node in the tree the depth of each nodes children differs by at most some tolerance.
      <T extends java.lang.Comparable<? super T>>
      boolean      		 BinaryTreeUtility.isBST​(BinaryTreeNode<T> root)
      A BinaryTreeNode is said to be a Binary Search Tree if all of the following properties are true: The left subtree of a node contains only nodes with values less than or equal to the value stored in root. The right subtree of a node contains only nodes with values that are greater than the value stored in root. The left and right subtree each must also be a binary search tree.
      void BinaryTreeNode.setLeftChild​(BinaryTreeNode<T> left)
      Sets the left child of this BinaryTreeNode.
      void BinaryTreeNode.setRightChild​(BinaryTreeNode<T> right)
      Sets the right child of this BinaryTreeNode.
